content:encoded:
Ubiq is proud to present POSTER 1 — HODLER, the second NFT in the ERC1155 Redeemable Poster series.

Introduction

Ubiq is proud to present the second redeemable ERC1155 NFT on the Ubiq platform. This was drawn by the talented artist Bassment Rats.

This is available now for 200 UBQ and is only available in a limited quantity of 88. That’s right, only 88 will ever exist.

Available at: https://poster.ubiqsmart.com

Since this is a digital asset, you can buy the poster and hold it. You have the freedom to redeem it later or transfer it to another address. While we don’t currently have a secondary market for NFTs for Ubiq (this is in the works), there is also the possibility to resell an unredeemed token.

POSTER 1 — HODLER is a 12 x 18 inch poster printed on museum quality matte paper. Every redeemed poster ships for free worldwide to any country which doesn’t have legal restrictions on imports (Cuba, Iran, Crimea, Syria, and North Korea).

The HODLER poster pays tribute to Ubiq and the crypto community with the concept of “Hodl” and being a “Hodler” of crypto. HODLER contains many elements of the wider Ubiq ecosystem such as Sparrow and Escher.

Artist statement

The world is changing fast, but the the internet world faster.
Nowadays people have the opportunity to be part of those changes through the Crypto world.
In a way people are getting the power back to their hands by cutting out the middleman and securing their ownerships.
As a creative person, I’m always looking for new ways and platforms to express my art and beliefs.
It took me some time to understand what the possibilities are, but after 10 years of peering into the crypto ecosystem, I can say that there is a new path that everybody should follow.
“ Hodler ”
Bassment Rats

Update on the Poster Shop project

The response to the first Ubiq NFT was overwhelming.

I honestly expected the poster to linger around for weeks unsold. It was great to see that the Ubiq community has grown and that the poster sold out in 34 minutes!

A lot of preparation work was done to make it all work smoothly and safely. It all went through flawlessly and we even had to ship an update to add some Sold Out logic. We learned a lot and will be iterating on the Poster Shop web site with updates over time.

The undertaking of working with multiple artists for more posters is underway. This is a truly collaborative process and we look forward to bringing new art to the Ubiq community as well as showcasing some terrific artists. A lot of artists are gaining exposure to crypto and NFTs through Ubiq so this is great to see.

Projects like this can only go as far as the community supports us. It has been great to see redeemed posters framed and pictures shared on social media. Community support and enthusiasm means we can continue bringing more exciting projects to the Ubiq ecosystem.

We have more posters lined up and we are hard at work on a new generative art NFT project.

Cheers,

Julian

Ubiq is proud to present POSTER 0 — SHINOBI, the first NFT to launch on the Ubiq platform.

Introduction

Ubiq is proud to present the first redeemable ERC1155 NFT on the Ubiq platform. This was drawn by the talented artist and member of the Ubiq community, TunaChum.

This is available now for 88 UBQ and is only available in a limited quantity of 88. That’s right, only 88 will ever exist.

Available at: https://poster.ubiqsmart.com

Since this is a digital asset, you can buy the poster and hold it. You have the freedom to redeem it later or transfer it to another address. While we don’t currently have a secondary market for NFTs for Ubiq (this is in the works), there is also the possibility to resell an unredeemed token.

POSTER 0 — SHINOBI is a 12 x 18 inch poster printed on museum quality matte paper. Every redeemed poster ships for free worldwide to any country which doesn’t have legal restrictions on imports (Cuba, Iran, Crimea, Syria, and North Korea). The SHINOBI poster pays tribute to our decentralized trading platform Shinobi.

Technical details

POSTER is an ERC1155 contract which differs from the original ERC721 Non-Fungible Token standard in a few ways, one of them being that the ERC1155 standard allows you to have a collection of NFTs under the one contract. We hope that this first poster is successful and that we can bring more exciting posters to the public.

We have also deployed a Poster Shop contract which allows the purchasing of POSTER 0 through a Dapp.

Our smart contracts are available on GitHub: https://github.com/ubiq/ubiq-poster-erc1155

The ERC1155 contract uses standard contracts from OpenZeppelin whereas the Poster Shop contract was written from scratch but includes full test cases in the codebase.

In building the Poster Shop, we took inspiration from the Unisocks project however this felt this model of Automated Market Maker (AMM) pricing does not work out favorably as it will never reach a scenario where all of the units will be sold out and the pricing curve quickly hits a point of being undesirable.

Background

On a personal level, this release symbolizes a journey which has come full circle from my earlier days in crypto. Jumbucks Crypto Community Cards was the first crypto asset project I worked on back in 2014 but that was when the crypto community was much smaller.

While this was a good overall project, we weren’t able to put out more cards in the series (we had plans for over 100 cards) since the crypto community was too small. In retrospect, a lot of the ambitious projects which launched in this time period were just ahead of their time.

I’ve spent my fair share of crypto funds on purchases and other experiments so I am a firm believer in active user engagement in the crypto economy. “HODL” for the sake of just inactively holding funds leads us to the Ponzi scheme mechanics of investments.

Having been involved in crypto since 2013, this scene and industry has been life affirming and life changing. I’m happy to see where the industry has progressed. Hopefully we can continue to change the world one decentralized transaction at a time.

title: Announcing the Taurus Hard Fork and Gubiq 5.0
content:encoded:
This article formally announces the Taurus Hard Fork with upgrade details.

Hard fork block

Taurus is the next hard fork for Ubiq and is planned to activate at block 1,500,000, currently estimated for March 20, 2021.

Changes

The Taurus hark fork has been in development and testing for the past few months by the Ubiq core development team.

This update will activate Istanbul EIP’s from upstream Ethereum.

This release also sets the default miner minimum gas price from 1 to 10 Gwei. Historically, this was originally set as 18 Gwei however this was set to 1 Gwei in a merge from upstream Geth. This change helps to promote a healthier fee market moving forward.

The next release of Gubiq is anticipated to be a maintenance release that will also include some new features from the Ubiq team including more advanced transaction tracing.

Gubiq 5.0

Gubiq 5.0 full node is now available:
https://github.com/ubiq/go-ubiq/releases/tag/v5.0.0

All services which run Ubiq nodes must upgrade ASAP. Fusion wallet will be updated to point to the latest version and you will automatically be prompted to upgrade.

Outreach

This is a call to the community to please actively inform others about the Ubiq hard fork upgrade and to contact services and software providers that you currently use.

FAQ

Here are some further questions not covered in the above:

What do I have to do with my coins?

Nothing. Ubiq holders can simply keep their coins on a private wallet, hardware wallet or on exchange.

Will I have to update Fusion?

Fusion will prompt you to update your version of Gubiq. The Fusion front end can remain unchanged.

Does this mean we will have two Ubiq chains like ETH and ETC?

This hard fork is part of our roadmap. This hard-fork upgrade is not contentious and therefore the likelihood of a chain split is low.

Are the exchanges supporting the upgrade?

Exchange partners have been notified of the update and we do not anticipate any issues.

Are hardware wallets supporting the upgrade?

Your hardware wallet requires no changes to use the upgraded chain. Wallet software like Pyrus and Sparrow will be updated with no effect on your Ledger or Trezor.

title: ubiq-config
content:encoded:
A simple utility for managing your single-board Ubiq node.

For the last few years, the Ubiq community has made available various guides and simple programs aimed at helping individuals operate nodes on inexpensive hardware. Some were supplemental, describing easy ways to perform updates. Others were focused on extending the capabilities of those systems to include new functionality, such as sending transactions routed through your own node, or hosting a local instance of Shinobi.

The goal has always been to provide methods that are approachable and straightforward. Enough so that anyone can support the network without first needing to learn various new skills, or be required to invest significant amounts of time or money in order to participate.

The latest contribution is a text-based user interface called ubiq-config. It is reminiscent of tools such as raspi-config and armbian-config that ship as part of Raspberry Pi OS and Armbian OS. Until now, the least complicated methods to install, update, or otherwise interact with a Ubiq node involved occasionally inputting various commands to execute different scripts. While it was not the most daunting experience, it did incur some friction. That is what ubiq-config is meant to address.

Users will now only have to go through that process once during the initial setup, afterwords only needing to access this new utility in order to manage the system. Beyond configuring a new node, ubiq-config is also a convenient tool for existing nodes. If you used the methods from the previous guides to install gubiq, then ubiq-config is for you as well.

Essentially, ubiq-config is a bash script like those described in previous articles. However, being executed from /usr/bin allows the user to call it while working from anywhere in the operating system. Now there is only one item to keep track of and no directories to remember. It can be used while logged in as either pi or node, and will only allow the proper user to employ the applicable options.

If you are unfamiliar with installing the correct OS to the microSD card, how to log in to the system via SSH, or other pre-install setup details, you can find all of that information in detail here.

To install;

Log in as pi on Raspberry Pi OS or as root on Armbian OS.

Input the following three commands —

wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/maaatttt/ubiq/master/ubiq-config.sh

chmod 755 ubiq-config.sh

sudo mv ubiq-config.sh /usr/bin/ubiq-config

Thats it!

Going forward, whenever you input ubiq-config the system will present a familiar, easy-to-navigate interface for you to manage your node.

Thanks for being part of the Ubiq community!

NOTE: At the moment there seem to be issues installing Shinobi Interface on older OS installs. However, if you are using a completely fresh setup, it will work fine. This post will be updated once the issue has been solved.

content:encoded:
Using Shinobi — Yield Farming and Token Generation Events

Welcome to a new series of posts aimed to explain the components of Shinobi.

Today we will look at the concepts of Yield Farming and Token Generation Events, which are being brought to the Ubiq Network and complement the Shinobi ecosystem.

What is Yield Farming and what is a Token Generation Event?

Yield farming is a new concept which caught on in 2020 with the rising popularity of Uniswap on Ethereum.

In its essence, Yield farming is a way of earning a return from your cryptocurrencies by providing liquidity to a pairing on Shinobi and then staking your Shinobi Liquidity Provider Tokens (SLPT) for a period of time. This is a potential way to mitigate the risk of Impermanent Loss and increase liquidity and price stability to a trading pair

The concept of Impermanent Loss has been covered in previous guides, and we recommend reading through these to familiarize yourself before taking advantage of a yield farming opportunity.

Token Generation Events or TGEs are one way of providing an opportunity to farm yield. With your staked SLPT you can earn your yield in a brand new token, which has its own individual purpose and market. The new token has an issuance model which we will explain when launched, but will be rewarded to participants staking their SLPT each block that passes.

Ubiq is currently planning to launch several of these incentives in 2021. In preparation, we recommend the community spends some time reading this guide.

How to farm yield on Ubiq

The first step to farming yield is to provide liquidity to a pairing on Shinobi. To do this, we first recommend reading the guides below:

  • The Ubiq DEX — Introducing Shinobi
  • The Ubiq DEX — Liquidity Pools

Please also ensure you have installed Sparrow and read the following guide:

The Ubiq DEX — Using Sparrow

You may also choose to use MetaMask instead of Sparrow. In which case read this guide:

Adding Ubiq to Metamask

We also recommend reading up on the TGE launch article posted recently:

Launch of the Ubiq Token Generation Event Framework

How do I see how much SLPT I have?

We will assume for simplicity that you are adding liquidity to the UBQ-ESCH pairing. Once you have added liquidity, in order to see SLPT in your wallet, you will need to add the pair address to Sparrow or MetaMask.

You can find the Pair Address that needs to be added on the Shinobi-Info page for the pairing you wish to add.

The icon next to the pair address will automatically add it to your clipboard for pasting.

Once you have the pair address copied, open Sparrow or MetaMask, log into your account and click the ‘Add Token’ button on the primary screen.

You will then be presented with the ‘Add Tokens’ screen. Click on ‘Custom Token’ and paste the pair address into the ‘Token Contract Address’ field. The Token Symbol and Decimals should automatically populate.

Once the fields have been correctly filled out, click next and you will be asked if you want to add these tokens to your wallet to watch. Please note that the tokens are already actually at your address, you are simply configuring Sparrow or MetaMask so you can monitor how many you have.

Once you click ‘Add Tokens’ you will be able to see how many tokens you hold at this address at any point within the toolset.

The Ubiq TGE Framework

As outlined above, the Ubiq TGE Framework has been developed to increase liquidity on Shinobi by providing users an opportunity to stake their SLPT.

The below guide was based on our test website which can now be accessed by the community using the following link:

Farm Ubiq TGE1 tokens.

Please note that the TGE1 tokens shown in these examples are used for the purpose of testing the system while in development. As these are now also farmable by the wider community, but TGE1 is not expected to have any value as it is intended to be a test token to demonstrate the yield farming dApp interface. There will also likely be further articles outlining our ambitions for future TGEs.

Unlocking Your Wallet

The first step to using the TGE Framework is to unlock your wallet by associating it with your copy of Sparrow or MetaMask. You can do this by clicking on the ‘Unlock Wallet’ button.

Depending on what tool you are using, you will need to select from a pop-up what wallet provider you wish to use. For the rest of this guide, we will use Sparrow as the example. Click ‘Select’ underneath the Sparrow icon.

This will trigger your install of Sparrow/MetaMask to pop up with a password request. Add the password associated with your wallet.

Once your password has been accepted, the site will update with your individual metrics. You can see your currently staked LP tokens and any unharvested tokens that you have been farming.

At the top right-hand side of the screen, the Unlock Wallet button has also been replaced with ‘View Balances’.

title: Happy 4th Birthday Ubiq!
content:encoded:
Four years ago on January 28th, the genesis block occurred on the Ubiq network and the switch was made from Jumbucks. Years of evaluating various codes and protocols led the core development team to pursuing an Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM) compatible network that included improvements to the monetary policy, DAG growth, block times, and distribution model. Ubiq was launched without a premine and did not ICO, providing an equal opportunity for all to enter into the decentralized proof of work (PoW) platform. The intention was to provide a more stable alternative to Ethereum with various improvements. As you read below, note that the Gubiq updates follow the upstream Geth updates after the changes have gone auditing and testing by the core Ubiq development team. Ubiq has remained lock-step with Ethereum in it’s core network development with an update coming in the next few days.

There are quite a few articles posted by community members chronicling the developments and events involving Ubiq over the last 4 years. Listed below are the major network and core infrastructure developments that have occurred over the last 4 years:

Year 1 - 2017

  • Genesis Block, Fusion Wallet, Mining support
  • Partnerships with Einstein and Cryptopia exchanges
  • Pyrus Introduced — Offline wallet
  • Sparrow Released — MetaMask Fork
  • Ubiq named 2017 Canadian Blockchain Company of the Year
  • Inflation 7.29% with Mining Reward per block at 8

Year 2 - 2018

  • Gubiq 1.5.14 updated
  • Governance Released — Escher token announced with 8 airdrops
  • Escher Airdrops 1 and 2
  • Whiteblock study — TL;DR Ubiq had 2X increase in throughput and 90% lower uncle rate.
  • First Ubiq Improvement Proposal, UIP 1 — Vote to hard fork to change to Ubqhash to mitigate 51% attack.
  • Inflation 6.00% with Mining Reward per block at 7

Year 3 - 2019

  • Octano Labs Introduced-EVM support with Ubiq focus
  • Escher Airdrops 3, 4, 5 and 6
  • Gubiq updates 2.1, 2.2, 2.3
  • Andromeda Hard Fork
  • Inflation 4.89% with Mining Reward per block at 6

Year 4 - 2020

  • Gubiq updates 3.1, 3.2
  • Tornado Cash implementation
  • Escher Airdrops 7, and 8
  • UIP voted to disable Escher minting. Escher airdrops completed.
  • Spectrum Update
  • Ubiq Explorer Update
  • Shinobi Launch — Uniswap V.2 Fork
  • Sparrow Update to use with Shinobi
  • Inflation 3.91% with Mining Reward per block at 5

As we head into the 5th year, the infrastructure is now in place to begin building decentralized applications (dApps) and utilizing the Ubiq Ninja interface. To assist with broadening the market reach, there will be a bridge to Ethereum so that a market on Uniswap can be created. Ubiq coins will be wrapped and tokenized as wUbq and paired up with Eth, creating a wUbq/Eth market. A Dai bridge is also being evaluated so that funds can port over from various markets and wallets.

To encourage liquidity growth on Shinobi, there will be Token Generating Events (TGEs) that will give Ubq/Esch liquidity providers tokens for the dApps being launched on the network by the core development team. Core Dev Julian Yap just released the following article introducing TGEs https://blog.ubiqsmart.com/launch-of-the-ubiq-token-generation-event-framework-842bd50274cd.

It’s an exciting time where ideas are no longer ethereal. Liquidity in Shinobi has increased over 400% to start the new year, just breaching the $1.5 million mark. Community members and investors are now testing the staking mechanism for the TGEs as a new crop of defi participants enter the decentralized market place. The promise of decentralized networks is here and now the 4 years of infrastructure building has provided the tools and platform to realize a self-governing decentralized blockchain system.

Happy 4th Birthday Ubiq and cheers to promise-filled 5th year!

content:encoded:
The first Yield farm (a form of staking) has been launched for Ubiq. This farm serves 2 purposes which is to introduce the community to Yield farming and to set up the concept of the Ubiq Token Generation Event (TGE) Framework.

Introduction

Decentralized Finance (DeFi) has come a long way in the past year. We are excited by what the future brings and the team at Ubiq are eager to bring you the advancements we have seen in the wider crypto ecosystem.

Yield Farming has been one development which at its core has built upon the concept of staking but also helps to incentivize the act of being a Liquidity Provider in a market.

Through staking Liquidity Provider tokens from designated Shinobi Liquidity Pool(s) to a staking contract, we are able to then incentivize and provide a 3rd token as “yields” to this process.

The core developers at Ubiq really like the mechanics of Yield Farming as providing liquidity creates the equivalent of a deeper order book, providing greater market confidence so has a useful economic function. This is far better than a system where there is just pure staking without any further functionality other than to prove ownership.

Token Generation Event (TGE) Framework

Token Generation Events (TGEs) act as the means of distribution for a token through the use of Yield Farming ESCH-UBQ Liquidity Provider (LP) tokens.

This fulfills one of the primary goals that we originally outlined for ESCH almost 3 years ago.

Escher, like the artist and paintings, will be multi purpose and so it can form the basis of proposals and token protocol implementations. The goal is to have Escher extended to have additional utility in the form of protocol tokens. These protocol tokens will either be in the form of using ESCH itself or through staking ownership of ESCH+UBQ redeemable for a protocol token via a smart contract.

TGEs can vary in metrics but are expected to be based on the Ubiq Token Generation Event Framework project.

Distribution over time

Token distribution will follow a ratio similar to the following: 80% of tokens will distributed in the first 3 months to Yield Farming. This is known as the Early distribution phase. 20% of tokens will be distributed in the next 3 years to Yield Farming. This is known as the Long Tail distribution phase. 0% of tokens will be allocated elsewhere. There will be no “team”, “investor” or otherwise “premined” tokens.

There is expected to be varying months and years for the Early and Long Tail distribution phases depending on the project.

Tokens

The final tokens will be used as their own form of utility as well as governance for their respective project.

TGE1

TGE1 is the proof of concept of the TGE framework.

You can use your ESCH-UBQ LP tokens to start Yield Farming TGE1 now at: https://tge1.ubiqsmart.com

There will be live Token Generation Events solely dedicated to upcoming protocol tokens. The TGE Framework is the basic sample code for other projects to utilize yield farming for token distribution.

We anticipate there will be further TGE (for example TGE2, TGE3, etc..) proof of concept tokens as we experiment with more advanced DeFi contracts with features such as geysers, multipliers, governance and rebasing.

TGE1 also acts like an educational tool and faucet that people can test out LP Yield Farming.

TGE1 Yield Farming utilizes the battle tested and audited Synthetix staking smart contracts.

You can find the TGE1 Yield Farming smart contract source code here: https://github.com/ubiq/ubiq-tge-yieldfarm

You can find the TGE1 token smart contract source code here: https://github.com/ubiq/ubiq-tge1-token

TGE1 will follow the following emission schedule:

Early distribution: First 5 months, 8 million TGE1

Long tail distribution: Following 10 years, 2 million TGE1

We are sure this will be the first time many in the community have tried Yield Farming so feel free to stop by Ubiq Discord for any questions.

We have plans and look forward to bringing you further protocol tokens to the Ubiq network and live Token Generation Events in 2021 and beyond!

Enjoy!

Thanks for checking in and be sure to follow the blog, Twitter, Github and join Ubiq Discord to help collaborate with the best community on the internet.

Hosting your own instance of Ubiq’s Automated Market Maker.

In the Ubiq ecosystem, things trend toward decentralization. It can seem trite. After all, “decentralization” has long been a prevailing buzzword of the wider cryptocurrency industry. Sometimes it’s platitudes, while in other cases it reflects an actual ethos that some projects strive toward. Ubiq is undoubtedly the latter.

In 2020, a significant addition to the Ubiq sphere was Shinobi. A custom code-fork of Uniswap V2, it is a foundational component needed to open the chain to wider interoperability. With its introduction, there is now a familiar and permission-less way to maneuver between UBQ and the various tokens that are utilizing the Ubiq chain.

There is much more on the horizon for Ubiq’s AMM, but since we are talking decentralization here, let’s do something practical.

In previous guides we have shown how to maintain a full node for Ubiq on inexpensive single-board computers such as the Raspberry Pi. We have also shown how to use a web3 wallet like Sparrow or Metamask to route transactions through those nodes.

The logic for Shinobi lives on-chain in the form of smart contracts and therefore exists within the storage of all full nodes. The portion of the system that exists off-chain is the graphical interface. Wider distribution of which can benefit the whole network; just like the nodes themselves.

Since 2021 appears to be the year that AMM’s will become truly dominant, it is important that if we tout our permission-less bonafides that we continue to expound upon the tools to achieve it.

So, let’s install and use the Shinobi interface from the same hardware on which we are running our nodes!

Depending how your system is configured, either use ssh to gain access or input the commands directly.

Log in as the default user.

For example —

User pi if you are using Raspberry Pi OS.

User root if you are using Armbian.

Be sure to have changed the default password.

Input the commands —

wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/maaatttt/ubiq/master/shinobi.sh

sudo chmod +x shinobi.sh

./shinobi.sh

If prompted, respond to questions during the install with y or yes.

Make note of the IP address information, including the port number (8888) when it is displayed upon completion of the setup. You will be prompted to reboot.

You do not need to log back in to the system.

Using the browser in which you may have previously installed Sparrow, (and added your node details in Settings / Networks) enter the IP address information into the address bar that was presented to you previously.

The Shinobi swap page should now be displayed!

By hosting your own network node, routing transactions through it with Sparrow, and serving your own portal to Shinobi, you are using a suite of tools that allows for greater control over your interactions with Ubiq.

content:encoded:
Using Shinobi — A guide on Transaction Nonces

Welcome to a new series of posts aimed to explain the components of Shinobi.

Today we are issuing a quick guide for the community on transaction Nonces, explaining the order of them, what happens when they get out of the correct order and how to fix it. Whilst this is not an issue exclusive to interacting on Shinobi, we have seen an increase in the number of this type of issue, since its inception.

What is a Cryptographic nonce?

A Nonce in cryptography is an arbitrary random number created for a specific transaction that is only used once. It is issued by the underlying protocol (Bitcoin, Ethereum or Ubiq as examples) to ensure that the same number is not used twice and is there to protect the network from a replay attack.

For more information, here is a link to the wikipedia page.

Cryptographic nonce

Nonce ordering and what happens if they get out of order?

In Ubiq (as with Ethereum), each transaction you make from an account increases your nonce value by 1.

All Nonces must be in order, meaning Nonce 2 cannot be processed before Nonce 1 has been processed. The protocol will not process your transaction if you are trying to make transactions out of order.

The Nonces can get out of order if you submit a transaction with a gas price too low for miners to process. For example, if you make a transaction with a Nonce value of 3 (meaning the 3rd transaction made from this account) and an insufficient gas price so this does not process, the following transactions you make will have a value of 4, 5, 6, 7… etc. Because of the way the protocol functions, these will have to process in order, meaning none of them will confirm until the 3rd transaction is fixed.

How do I fix it? (Simple Version with a single broken transaction)

First, make sure you have enough gas in your account to pay transaction fees.

To demonstrate how to fix this issue, I made two transactions in Sparrow. The first (nonce 114) has a Gas price of 0 GWEI (meaning the miner will earn nothing from processing the transaction (guaranteeing it will not be processed). The second (nonce 115) has the current standard network gas price of 13.2 GWEI.

Both transactions are now pending and have not confirmed. The first transaction will never clear because of the gas price being set to 0 and the second transaction is unable to clear, as the protocol will not allow it to process out of order.

You can see both transactions in Sparrow (and MetaMask), by clicking on Activity:

The top transaction (nonce 114) is sitting in pending, causing the subsequent transaction to stay queued.

Click the ‘Speed Up’ button.

You will be presented with the ‘Customize Gas’ screen. Click ‘Advanced’.

In the ‘Gas Price (GWEI)’ field, enter 20 (standard gas fee), then click ‘Save’.

The transaction is now updated in sparrow, showing the updated gas price of 20 GWEI.

115 will also process in the same block as 114 as there are no longer any issues preventing them from being mined.

How do I fix it? (Longer Version with multiple broken transactions)

We have recently had a number of users join the discord and have failed to use the above method of clearing transactions, due to them making multiple transactions with no gas. The below guide can be used to identify and clear multiple failed transactions, by sending a 0 value transaction to your own account with a custom nonce setting.

Before we get started, please make sure that the account you are attempting to fix has some UBQ (1 UBQ should suffice) to pay the gas fees in the first place.

In this tutorial I will look at a scenario where 4 transactions have been made, each sending 1 UBQ to another account. The first 3 transactions have been made with 0 gas, and are therefore unable to process. with the 4th transaction having adequate gas, but unable to process due to the nonces being out of order.

Below is a screenshot of these transactions in pending on Ubiqscan:

Pending transactions will remain in Ubiqscan until they are cleared, so they are one method of identifying your account having a transaction issue, if you look for your account ID you can quickly see what is pending.

Ubiqscan orders the transactions in the order they were received from top to bottom, so the nonces will also be displayed sequentially from top to bottom. If we click the first one on this list we can see the first issue that was caused:

As you can see from the screenshot above, nonce 160 cannot process due to there being insufficient gas price set. Let’s have a look at the 3 other transactions:

As we can see from the other screenshots, nonces 161 and 162, in addition to 160 also have insufficient gas. These three will have to be cleared before transactions can return to normal from this account.

You can also see the broken transactions by looking at the activity page in Sparrow:

Clicking each of these transactions will also give you the same information for which nonce is broken. They are also ordered sequentially.

OK, now we understand what is broken and why, lets fix it. First, lets enable the ‘Customize Transaction Nonce’ setting in Sparrow.

Click the top right circular button and go to ‘Settings’.

Then click ‘Advanced’.

Next, scroll down and make sure that the ‘Customize Transaction Nonce’ button is turned on. It will look like this if correctly set:

Now, lets make a 0 value transaction to my own account with sufficient gas to start clearing out these broken transactions. Click send on the main Sparrow screen.

Then, click transfer between my accounts.

Select the same account you are sending from, to send too.

Next, make sure the amount is set to 0 and there is sufficient gas to process the transaction. Then click the next button.

Now, when you get to the confirmation screen, you should see the ‘Custom Nonce’ section. This will automatically populate with the next nonce, irrespective of the stuck transactions. We need to set this to the same nonce as the first broken transaction (160 in this case). Once you have entered this, click the confirm button.

Once the transaction is processed, the following confirmation from Sparrow will appear.

Nonce 160 has now been fixed and the original transaction no longer appears on Ubiqscan or Sparrow. As this specific example had 3 stuck transactions, the process will now need to be repeated with a custom nonce setting of 161 and 162. As 163 had the correct amount of gas this transaction will process as normal once the previous two have been cleared.

That’s it. If you have any more issues, feel free to drop into the Ubiq discord #help channel.

title: Announcing Gubiq 3.2
content:encoded:
This article formally announces the latest version of the Ubiq full node, Gubiq 3.2.

Introduction

Gubiq 3.2 is based on the 1.9.24 release of the upstream Go-Ethereum project and contains around 385 commits merged since the Gubiq 3.1 release that we made in August.

This is the first release which brings us full in-line with the latest release of the upstream Go-Ethereum project and has benefitted from Ubiq core developer Luke Williams having a full time role as a Core Geth developer.

This is highly recommended as all binaries are built with the latest Golang 1.15.5 release which includes a Go Ethereum reported security update, fixing CVE-2020–28362.

The next release of Gubiq is anticipated to be a hard fork activation release.

Gubiq 3.2

Gubiq 3.2 full node is now available:
https://github.com/ubiq/go-ubiq/releases/tag/v3.2.0

All services which run Ubiq nodes are encouraged to upgrade but this is considered an optional upgrade as there are no hard fork changes. Fusion wallet will be updated to point to the latest version and you will automatically be prompted to upgrade.

All services which run Ubiq nodes should at a minimum rebuild their nodes with the latest Golang 1.15.5 or above release and your preferred Gubiq 3.x release.

Changes

RPC.Discover (OpenRPC)

This release re-adds RPC.Discover (OpenRPC) support.

Sync optimizations

This release re-adds initial sync optimizations for Fast Sync.

Remove unsupported sync mode (light)

Light sync mode has never been supported with Ubiq so this has been removed in the codebase.

Enjoy!

Thanks for checking in and be sure to follow the blog, Twitter, Github and join Ubiq Discord to help collaborate with the best community on the internet.

Medium blog: https://blog.ubiqsmart.com
Twitter: https://twitter.com/ubiqsmart
Twitter: https://twitter.com/CryptoUbiq (Ubiq Community)
GitHub: https://github.com/ubiq
Website: http://ubiqsmart.com
